This date marks the beginning of Alvaro Uribe's presidency, which established his political identity as a hardline anti-communist leader and laid the foundation for his later legal challenges.
The original conviction occurred in August 2025, during which Uribe was sentenced to 12 years of house arrest, triggering national and international scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: Alvaro Uribe, Colombia's former president (2002–2010), had been convicted in August 2025 on charges of fraud and bribery, stemming from allegations that his lawyer bribed jailed paramilitaries to discredit links to paramilitary organizations.

The Superior Court in Bogotá overturned both convictions in October 2025, citing lack of credibility in testimony from former paramilitary commander Luis Carlos Velez and illegal wiretapping used in the investigation.

The ruling is significant because it challenges the legitimacy of a key piece of evidence — the testimony of Velez — and raises questions about the legality and transparency of investigative methods used in high-level political cases.

The decision has sparked political reactions: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio criticized the conviction, calling it an overreach, while President Gustavo Petro condemned the ruling as an attempt to cover up the history of paramilitary alliances with drug trafficking.

The case highlights deep-seated tensions in Colombia between political factions, the role of paramilitary groups in the country’s violence, and the ongoing struggle over accountability in post-conflict governance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombia's former president Alvaro Uribe has had two convictions for fraud and bribery overturned by the Superior Court in Bogotá, which found the testimony of former paramilitary commander Luis Carlos Velez to be uncredible and criticized the illegal use of wiretaps in the investigation. The original conviction stemmed from allegations that Uribe’s lawyer, Diego Cadena, bribed jailed paramilitaries to discredit claims of ties to paramilitary organizations. The ruling has triggered political reactions, with US Secretary of State Marco Rubio criticizing the conviction and Colombian President Gustavo Petro denouncing the outcome as an effort to conceal the history of paramilitary groups linked to drug trafficking. This case highlights tensions in Colombia’s political and judicial system over accountability, transparency, and historical narratives of conflict.
title: Colombian court overturns former president Alvaro Uribe's conviction
